qas.question: Along with Cornell University, what institution is involved in the building of Cornell Tech?
What is the cost to build Cornell Tech?
On what island is Cornell Tech located?
About how much capital did Accelerator raise as of the middle of 2014?
How large is the Alexandria Center for Life Science in square meters?
In 2011, what school was built on Roosevelt Island?

context: The biotechnology sector is also growing in New York City, based upon the city's strength in academic scientific research and public and commercial financial support. On December 19, 2011, then Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice of Cornell University and <a0_0>Technion-Israel Institute of Technology<a0_0/> to build a <a1_0>US$2 billion<a1_0/> graduate school of applied sciences called <a5_0>Cornell Tech<a5_0/> on <a2_0>Roosevelt Island<a2_0/> with the goal of transforming New York City into the world's premier technology capital. By mid-2014, Accelerator, a biotech investment firm, had raised more than <a3_0>US$30 million<a3_0/> from investors, including Eli Lilly and Company, Pfizer, and Johnson & Johnson, for initial funding to create biotechnology startups at the Alexandria Center for Life Science, which encompasses more than 700,000 square feet (<a4_0>65,000<a4_0/> m2) on East 29th Street and promotes collaboration among scientists and entrepreneurs at the center and with nearby academic, medical, and research institutions. The New York City Economic Development Corporation's Early Stage Life Sciences Funding Initiative and venture capital partners, including Celgene, General Electric Ventures, and Eli Lilly, committed a minimum of US$100 million to help launch 15 to 20 ventures in life sciences and biotechnology.
